Marie Curie: Marie Curie was a pioneering scientist who made groundbreaking contributions to the fields of physics and chemistry. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and her research on radioactivity has had a lasting impact on our understanding of the atom and its properties.

Leonardo da Vinci: Leonardo da Vinci was a true Renaissance man, with interests in art, science, and engineering. He was a prolific inventor and artist, and his work continues to inspire and influence people around the world.

Mahatma Gandhi: Mahatma Gandhi was a political and spiritual leader who played a key role in India's struggle for independence from British rule. His philosophy of nonviolent resistance has inspired countless people around the world to work for peace and social justice.

Nelson Mandela: Nelson Mandela was a political leader and anti-apartheid activist who spent 27 years in prison before being released and going on to become the first black president of South Africa. His leadership and commitment to justice and equality continue to inspire people around the world.

Harriet Tubman: Harriet Tubman was an abolitionist and political activist who helped hundreds of enslaved people escape from the United States in the 19th century. Her bravery and dedication to the cause of freedom make her a true hero.
